sampleData.PIG333 E-DIAGNOSTICS COMPREHENSIVE DATAB: COMPREHENSIVE VERSION - ALL DISEASES WITH COMPLETE DATA

sampleData.description: Newborn piglets in first week of life
Pre-weaned piglets from 8 days to weaning

sampleData.short_description: Disease of bacterial origin with high respiratory impact. Production of toxins can cause sudden death with nasal hemorrhage.
Usually subclinical, mainly affects piglets causing diarrhea.
Characterized by diarrhea in piglets within first few hours of birth.

sampleData.notes: Typical age 8-16 weeks, most common in growers
Typical age 8-16 weeks, most common in growers

sampleData.detailed_description: Pleuropneumonia caused by Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae. At least 15 serotypes exist with varying virulence. Toxin production causes severe pulmonary damage. Incubation period as short as 3 hours. Affects pigs 8-16 weeks typically. Can cause sudden death with minimal signs.
sampleData.key_symptoms: Sudden death, nasal hemorrhage, high fever, blue ears, severe respiratory distress, coughing, depression
sampleData.causes_transmission: Aerosol transmission over short distances. Carried in tonsils and upper respiratory tract. Survives outside pig only few days. Stress and coinfections (PRRS, influenza) trigger clinical disease in carriers.
sampleData.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs + sudden death + nasal hemorrhage + post-mortem pleuropneumonia. Laboratory: bacterial culture, PCR, serology. Important to identify serotype for vaccination.
sampleData.control_prevention: Vaccination with appropriate serotypes. Select App-negative replacement stock. Strategic medication at risk periods. In outbreaks examine population 3x daily for early detection.
sampleData.treatment: Mass injection of entire group immediately (dont wait for individual symptoms). Wide range of antibiotics effective. Injectable route essential as sick pigs dont eat/drink. Early treatment critical.

sampleData.detailed_description: Usually subclinical infection mainly affecting piglets causing diarrhea. Generally mild clinical significance.
sampleData.key_symptoms: Diarrhea in piglets, usually mild and self-limiting
sampleData.causes_transmission: Fecal-oral transmission. Environmental contamination. Carrier animals.
sampleData.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs and fecal culture. Usually diagnosed retrospectively.
sampleData.control_prevention: Good hygiene and sanitation. Proper cleaning between batches.
sampleData.treatment: Usually self-limiting. Supportive care if needed. Antibiotics rarely necessary.

sampleData.detailed_description: Diarrhea caused by enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) affecting mainly lactating piglets with high mortality. Different strains produce different toxins (K88, K99, F18). Three main presentations: neonatal diarrhea (first 4 days), post-weaning diarrhea, and edema disease.
sampleData.key_symptoms: Watery diarrhea, severe dehydration, pale pigs, high mortality in neonates, weakness
sampleData.causes_transmission: Fecal-oral route. Environmental contamination. Poor hygiene. Inadequate colostrum. Cold damp conditions. Stress factors. High stocking density.
sampleData.diagnosis_methods: Clinical signs, age of pigs, post-mortem. Laboratory: bacterial culture identifying pathogenic strains and virulence factors. Antimicrobial sensitivity testing important.
sampleData.control_prevention: Good hygiene and management. Adequate colostrum intake. Warm dry environment. Sow vaccination for passive immunity. Reduce stress. Control stocking density.
sampleData.treatment: Oral or injectable antibiotics based on sensitivity. Fluid therapy for dehydration. Supportive care. Early treatment critical. Probiotics may help.

sampleData.Key Clinical Signs: Sudden death, nasal hemorrhage, respiratory distress
